monogr.title: Lavv, or, a discourse thereof : in foure bookes. Written in French by Sir Henrie Finch Knight, his Maiesties Serieant at Law. And done into English by the same author
monogr.author: Finch, Henry, Sir

div.head: To the READER.
div.p:
THis Booke, being formerly published in the proper and genuine Language, had, as it well deserued, good acceptation; the Author and the Work mutually adding to each others Esteeme. And herein the Matter was no lesse profitable, than the Manner vsefull and ingenious: so that this onely of al the Bookes of Law (as concerning the Method) is without President. Herein you may finde a
triple relation distinguished by the various Print. In the first, you haue the Maximes and positiue grounds of the Law, with whatsoeuer is added or explaned by Statutes concerning the same; Which taken apart will afford a continued sensible discourse. In the second is contained the proofes and examples of those Maximes. And because that precious Flower of the Crowne, the Kings Prerogatiue, may not bee valued in the hands of a common person, such cases as concerne the King are seuered from the rest.

To impart good is to improoue it, which was one cause of the translation of this Book: yet is it not thereby made so facile as to descend to vulgar capacities; witnesse the verie phrase, the termes of Art, excluding
all hope of accrue to Lay-conceited opinions. Neither speaketh it at aduenture, but as the Author taught, and no otherwise; whose fame will affirme, and none wil denie, but that he best knew how to fit and adorne his owne worke.

Now remaineth onely to ex
• enuat the faults, either those material in the copie, or literall • n the Print, the first a iudicious Reader is able to supplie, a litle • abour will correct the rest: He • hat is curteous wil remit both. To plot and to perfect at once • s to bee more than man. Such was the paine to compose that • he child wasted its owne pa
• ent, therein neuerthelesse be
• ng vnhappie preuenting the • lessing of Perfection, and be
• omming an Abrotiue; But be • ou the Guardian, so much It
inuites, the Author merits more. His proposed end was to enrich others by this expression of his Loue, couer therfore the faults occasioned by an Error of Loue, and redeeme Him that for your sake is imbarque • in the common Censure of al • Men.
